criteria.description: Can compute and interpret the Fourier series coefficients for periodic signals.
criteria.name: Fourier series understanding

criteria.description: Can relate signal characteristics to their spectral representation (e.g., bandwidth, harmonics).
criteria.name: Spectral interpretation

criteria.description: Can compute the Fourier transform for standard signals and understand magnitude and phase spectra.
criteria.name: Fourier transform application

outcomes.description: Students will be able to represent signals using Fourier series and Fourier transforms and interpret their spectra.
outcomes.name: Analyze signals in the frequency domain

criteria.description: Can compute and interpret the frequency response of discrete-time systems.
criteria.name: Frequency response analysis

criteria.description: Can design and implement basic FIR and IIR filters.
criteria.name: Filter design

criteria.description: Can derive and use Z-transforms to analyze discrete-time systems.
criteria.name: Z-transform usage

outcomes.description: Students will apply discrete-time system analysis and filtering techniques in the digital domain.
outcomes.name: Apply digital signal processing techniques

criteria.description: Can distinguish between continuous-time and discrete-time signals, and identify deterministic vs. random signals.
criteria.name: Signal classification

criteria.description: Understands linearity, time-invariance, causality, and stability in systems.
criteria.name: System properties

criteria.description: Applies basic operations such as time-shifting, scaling, and reversal to signals.
criteria.name: Basic transformations

outcomes.description: Students will be able to describe and analyze basic properties of continuous and discrete-time signals and systems.
outcomes.name: Understand the fundamentals of signals and systems

criteria.description: Validates computational results against theoretical predictions.
criteria.name: Simulation accuracy

criteria.description: Can generate and plot time-domain and frequency-domain representations of signals.
criteria.name: Signal visualization

criteria.description: Writes clean and modular code to implement DSP algorithms.
criteria.name: Code organization

outcomes.description: Students will use MATLAB or Python to simulate and analyze signals and systems.
outcomes.name: Use computational tools for signal processing

criteria.description: Understands ideal and practical reconstruction filters.
criteria.name: Signal reconstruction

criteria.description: Can identify aliasing effects in undersampled signals.
criteria.name: Aliasing recognition

criteria.description: Understands the Nyquist-Shannon sampling theorem and its implications.
criteria.name: Sampling theorem

outcomes.description: Students will understand the principles of signal sampling, aliasing, and reconstruction of continuous signals from discrete samples.
outcomes.name: Understand sampling and reconstruction
